div.h4:
Distance Learning Overview
Kindergarten-Grade 5
Hmong I Spanish
Grades 6-8
Hmong I Spanish
Grades 9-12
Hmong I Spanish

h3.style: font-size: 24px; font-family: latobold; font-weight: normal; color: rgb(40, 40, 40); line-height: 1.38; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;

div.h3: Distance Learning means that students will learn at home with access to educational materials and daily interaction with their teacher(s). Distance Learning can be accessed online through a computer or tablet device. Distance Learning without technology will only be available to families who have requested modifications.

br.strong: The State of Minnesota has ordered Distance Learning for schools to begin on Monday, March 30 and will continue through the end of the school year.

div.script:

                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_0","title":"Elementary School Distance Learning","content":"
Elementary School Distance Learning Expectations

Elementary families will access assignments and lessons using Seesaw. Classroom teachers and specialists will post activities daily, by 10 a.m. Monday-Friday. Teachers will be available by Seesaw, email or phone between the hours of 10 a.m.-12 p.m. and 1-3 p.m.



Families can expect school staff and grade-level teams to post activities in social-emotional learning, reading, writing, math, art, music, media and physical education. Students will be expected to participate in the activities and assignments posted by their teachers like a regular school day. Teachers will also provide feedback to students through Seesaw and may contact parents and guardians by email or phone. 

Distance Learning Without Technology

Teachers will prepare lessons and activities on a weekly basis. The modified work will include activities similar to the work being done in Seesaw. Students who are receiving the non-technology Distance Learning materials will receive their learning materials on Monday of each week. Arrangements to deliver materials will be made with families through the schools' principal. 

Elementary School Sample Schedule 

We recommend trying to maintain a schedule with students. To help in planning, we've provided a sample daily schedule. 

    
10 a.m.-12 p.m. Academic time
    
    
        
Seesaw examples: classroom activities
        
Choice Board examples: reading, math and social studies/science/health
    
    
    
12-12:30 p.m. Lunch
    
12:30-1 p.m. Household tasks, quiet time or outdoor time
    
    
        
Examples: assigned household chores, read to self, yoga, mindfulness activities, rest
    
    
    
1-3 p.m. Academic time
    
    
        
Seesaw example: specialist activities
        
Choice Board example: writing, specialists
    
    
    
3-3:30 p.m. Parent/student led creative time
    
    
        
LEGOs, drawing, coloring, play, music, cook, bake, outdoor activity, etc. 
    
    


Resources

Distance Learning is an adjustment for teachers, students and families and we understand that there will be questions and challenges. Please review the Seesaw resources below and reach out to your teacher with questions. 

Support for Students

    
How students post to an activity
    
How To post to an activity with a multimedia example (Video Lesson or Video Link)
    
Video - Students - How to sign in and access classes at home
    
Poster:  Students - How to sign in and access classes at home


Support for Families

    
Video
    
        
How to download the app (IOS)
        
How to download the app (Android)
    
    
    
Poster:  How to access Seesaw at home (students and families)
    
SoWashCo Seesaw Parent Info Page
    
Internet Access


We have also compiled a list of resources for families as you continue to provide learning at home. Find them under the “Elementary Learning Resources” tab.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_1","title":"Middle School Distance Learning","content":"
Middle School Distance Learning Expectations

All middle school students will access assignments and lessons using Schoology. Teachers will post activities daily, by 10 a.m. Monday-Friday and will be available by Schoology, email or phone between the hours of 10 a.m.-12 p.m. and 1-3 p.m.



In order to ensure time for high-quality Distance Learning, middle school class periods will be split every other day. Alternating days will ensure students can manage their workload and teachers have time to plan and provide quality learning and feedback. 



Students can expect instruction on the following schedule. 

    
Monday: Class periods 1-4 will post new information in Schoology
    
Tuesday:  Class periods 5-8 will post new information in Schoology
    
Wednesday: Advisory and all teachers will be available for individual and small group instruction
    
Thursday: Class periods 1-4 will post new information in Schoology
    
Friday:  Class periods 5-8 will post new information in Schoology


If a student’s typical class schedule lists class periods as a “double-blocked” class, for example class period 4/5, teachers will post on the day designated for the first hour listed first. For example, a  block for class periods 4/5 will post on Monday and Thursday for period four.



Students will be expected to participate in assignments posted by their teachers and then reply back with completed work. Teachers will use participation to record attendance. Teachers who have not heard back from a student may reach out to parents or guardians by email, phone or other modes of communication. 



Distance Learning activities will vary in the length of time required to complete the assignment. Each class assignment will take approximately 50-60 percent of the time students traditionally spend in class during a regular school day. 

Distance Learning Without Technology

Distance Learning without technology will only be available to families who have requested modifications. The modified work will include activities similar to the work being done in Schoology and teachers will deliver directions by phone. 



If any student still needs access to a device or internet, please contact your principal. 

Resources

Distance Learning is an adjustment for teachers, students and families and we understand that there will be questions and challenges. Please review the resources below and contact your teacher with questions.

    
Schoology Help for Students
    
Schoology Information for Parents
    
Internet Access

Students and parents who need assistance with Schoology can email for help at schoologyhelp@sowashco.org. 


We have also compiled a list of resources for families as you continue to provide learning at home. Find them under the “Secondary Learning Resources" tab.

Middle School Sample Schedule


We also recommend trying to maintain a schedule with students. To help in planning, we’ve provided a sample daily schedule.

    
10 a.m.-12 p.m. Academic time
    
        
Teachers available by email and phone
    
    
    
12-12:30 p.m. Lunch
    
12:30-1 p.m. Household tasks, quiet time or outdoor time
    
        
Examples: assigned household chores, read to self, yoga, mindfulness activities, rest
    
    
    
1-3 p.m. Academic time
    
        
Teachers available via email and phone
    
    
    
3-3:30 p.m. Parent/student led creative time
    
        
Legos, drawing, coloring, play music, cook, bake, outdoor activity
    
    
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_2","title":"High School Distance Learning","content":"
High School Distance Learning Expectations

All high school students will access assignments and lessons using Schoology. Teachers will post activities daily, by 10 a.m. Monday-Friday and will be available by Schoology, email or phone between the hours of 10 a.m.-12 p.m. and 1-3 p.m.



Students will be expected to participate in assignments posted by their teachers and then reply back with completed work. Teachers will use participation to record attendance. Teachers who have not heard back from a student may reach out to parents and guardians by email, phone or other modes of communication. 



Distance Learning activities will vary in the length of time required to complete the assignment. Each class assignment will take approximately 50-60 percent of the time students traditionally spend in class during a regular school day. This guidance may vary for some courses based on the course and content (i.e. College in the Schools courses, Advanced Placement, IB).

Distance Learning Without Technology

Distance Learning without technology will only be available to families who have requested modifications. The modified work will include activities similar to the work being done in Schoology and teachers will deliver directions by phone. 

Resources

Distance Learning is an adjustment for teachers, students and families and we understand that there will be questions and challenges. Please review the resources below and contact your teacher with questions. 

    
Schoology Help for Students
    
Schoology Information for Parents
    
Internet Access


On Tuesday, March 24 and Wednesday, March 25, some of our teachers will be posting activities in Schoology to practice teaching students online. It is not mandatory for students to participate, but we encourage them to log in to Schoology to check for posts from their teacher. ","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_3","title":"Technology Help","content":"Having issues with your device can be very frustrating.  Find Troubleshooting Tips and Tricks with your school issued devices on the Technology Resources page.
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_4","title":"Access to Devices","content":"
Students who do not have access to a device at home to complete their distance learning work should contact their school's main office. ","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_5","title":"Internet Accessibility","content":"

Comcast is offering two months free to new Internet Essentials customers in response to anticipated emergency measures associated with the COVID-19. 




Xfinity WiFi hotspots across the country will be available to anyone who needs them for free – including non-Xfinity Internet subscribers. For a map of Xfinity WiFi hotspots, visit www.xfinity.com/wifi. Once at a hotspot, consumers should select the “xfinitywifi” network name in the list of available hotspots, and then launch a browser.



CenturyLink offers Lifeline, a low-cost internet service, to individuals who qualify.



South Washington County Schools is providing this information as a courtesy to families, not as an endorsement of the services provided. Additional internet resources will be shared as we become aware of them. 
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_6","title":"Learning from Home Tips","content":"
When there are more people at home and using your internet, you may see a strain on the speed of your home internet connection. While we are not able to provide direct support to families with home devices and internet issues, we can offer these helpful suggestions: 

    
An appropriate first response to an error with a device is to power it down and start it back up (reboot). 
    
It’s helpful to have a plan for when and where family members will charge devices. 
    
When WiFi enabled electronics (cell phone, tablet, etc.) are not immediately in use, turn them off. 
    
During “academic” time, minimize media (Netflix, YouTube, Spotify) streaming to allow for the full use of internet bandwidth.


","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_7","title":"Grading","content":"We acknowledge the high-level of stress Distance Learning may cause for staff, students and parents and are using that as a lens to adjust our grading practices. Please see below for detailed information about each level. 


Elementary 
The goal of the elementary progress report is to provide meaningful information that families can use to team with teachers to support their student’s learning. With the move to Distance Learning, and the expectations in place for the exchange of communication between teachers and students, all reporting of grading in Infinite Campus has been suspended for the remainder of the 2020 school year. 


Middle School
With the move to Distance Learning, all Middle School courses will be graded on a Pass/No-Pass basis. Courses taken in middle school that receive high school credit will be graded in accordance with the high school grading standards, including; Geometry, Algebra 2, Algebra with Stats, Advance Physical Science, Spanish I, Chinese I. 


High School
Due to the uncertainty of the impact on college admission, NCAA eligibility, scholarships, and many things beyond the reach of our control, teachers will continue to grade students using traditional grading practices during Distance Learning. Teachers have flexibility to assign a Pass (P) or No Pass (N) for any course at their discretion, after consulting with the student or parents/guardians.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_8","title":"Attendance","content":"Attendance will be taken during the Distance Learning period. Accountability for learning (completing assignments) will be separated from “showing up for Distance Learning” (attendance). For the purpose of Distance Learning, attendance is defined as a student demonstrating that they are showing up for “school,” understanding the expected tasks for the day and ready to engage in learning. Teachers will outline what constitutes attendance for students.



To report an absence, parents/guardians can notify the classroom teacher or call the school’s attendance line.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_9","title":"State Assessments and ACT Testing","content":"Based on a March 20, 2020 announcement by U.S. Department of Education Secretary Betsy DeVos and Governor Walz’s Executive Order, districts will no longer administer statewide assessments (ACCESS, Alternate ACCESS, MCA, and MTAS) for the remainder of the 2019–20 school year.



Additionally, the ACT Plus Writing college entrance test that was originally scheduled for all 11th grade students on April 7 has been cancelled. The district is working with the ACT organization to determine alternative testing options for current 11th grade students. ACT does not permit testing at home. Once an alternative is finalized we will share it with you.


","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_10","title":"Live Virtual Classroom Guidelines","content":"A Live Virtual Classroom (LVC) is considered a face-to-face interaction between a teacher and a student, or group of students, using a virtual platform (i.e WebEx, Zoom, Google Hangout, Google Meet, Schoology Conferencing, FaceTime, etc) in real time.



Distance Learning has significantly increased teachers’ reliance on virtual learning environments. While we are in Distance Learning ordered by Governor Tim Walz during the COVID-19 pandemic, your child has the opportunity to participate in live virtual classroom experiences using a variety of platforms. While these virtual classrooms are occurring, you may encounter or become aware of information about other students, overhear conversations and observe student interactions. Confidentiality is highly important. By allowing your child to participate, you are also agreeing that you will not discuss or share any information about other students in the group and you also agree that during the session no recording or digital image retention of any kind will occur (including posting pictures or video on social media). Students are not required to participate in the live virtual classroom meetings. Please reach out to Kelly Jansen, kjansen@sowashco.org, with any questions. Thank you for your flexibility and patience as we work through this unprecedented challenge.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl28_divTabs_11","title":"Student Support Services","content":"
Special Education
All case managers will connect with all of their families, to check in and see how they are doing, to determine the best method to communicate with them, and also to deliver communication and materials about instruction.  Case managers should also let families know they are available for questions, to support learning, and to provide accommodations or modifications to general education assignments as appropriate.

English Learners (EL)

Provision of education for English learners are an important consideration when engaging in this planning. The school district remains responsible for educating English learners. We must plan how they will continue to meet the requirements of English learners' educational needs. 



Key Points:

    
By law, students who are identified to receive English language development services must be provided support that allow them access to academic content.
    
English learners must receive research based, appropriately resourced support to access content, and districts may not withhold services based on characteristics such as immigration status. Immediate considerations for English learners include:
    
        
Access to a reliable internet connection
        
Communication with families that may not speak English as a primary language
        
Ability of the student to understand and produce complex academic language for assignments without typical scaffolds
        
Availability of scaffolding methods that are available in a distance learning environment
        
Ultimately, English learners need to have the chance to access grade level standards and still need some sort of support to access academic content.
    
    


Families Experiencing Homelessness or in Housing Transition

In the event you are experiencing homelessness or are in a housing transition, please reach out to the District’s Homeless Liaison for assistance.  This includes assessing food needsand confirming access to devices and internet access.

District Homeless Liaison

Crystal Gentry

(651) 425-3765

Cgentry@sowashco.org","active":false,"disabled":false}],// required,

                        propTitle: 'title', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propActive: 'active', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes

                        tabMode : tabM,

                    }).on('ready.scrtabs', function() {
                        $('#'+this.id+' .tab-pane').attr('tabindex',0);
                    });
                };

                activate();
            }
        }
    });
